questions.uddipok:

require an article. Put a cross (×) in those blanks: —
William Shakespeare was born on April 23, 1564 in (a) ———village of Stratford-on-Avon in (b) ———-country of
Warwickshire. His father John Shakespeare was (c) ————farmer's son who came (d) ————-Stratford about 1531, and began to prosper as (e) ———-trader in corn, wheat, leather and agricultural products. His mother Mary Arden was (f) —————daughter of (g) ——————prosperous farmer, descended from (h) ————-old family of mixed Anglo-Saxon and Norman blood. It is generally believed that neither (i) ———-poet's mother nor his father could read or write. In 1582, Shakespeare married Anne Hathaway, the daughter of (j) ————— peasant family. She was eight years older than Shakespeare.

questions.uddipok:
Read the text and fill in the gaps with the correct form of verbs as per subject and context.
Trees contribute a lot (a) ____(maintain) ecological balance. A month-long tree fair (b) ____ (begin) in Kurigram stadium recently. It (c) ____ (organize) by the local administration and the Department of Social Forestation. The fair (d) ____ (inaugurate) yesterday by the DC of Kurigram. questions.uddipok:
Read the text and change the sentences as directed: —
Bangladeshi developers can build modern robots like Sophia using its software.
(a) The humanoid robot, Sophia is one of the newest sensations in the ICT world. (Make it positive)
(b) Honourable Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina met Sophia, at the inaugural ceremony of the four-day-long
digital world expo. (Make it passive)
(c) The Hong Kong-based Robotics Company developed Sophia, one and a half year ago. (Make it complex)

sub_questions.explanation:
(a) Very few sensations in the ICT world are as new as Sophia, the humanoid robot.
(b) Sophia was met by honourable Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina at the inaugural ceremony of the four-daylong

(c) It is one and a half year ago when the Hong Kong-based Robotics Company developed Sophia.
(d) The robot wore a yellow Jamdani top and skirt and came on the stage.
(e) The robot generated a great enthusiasm among the youth.

questions.uddipok:
Change the narrative style by using indirect speeches.
"You've cut off your hair?" asked Jim. "Cut it off and sold it," said Della. Don't you like me just as well, anyhow? I'm me without my hair, ain't I?" "You say your hair is gone?" he said. "You don't have to look for it. Shall we eat dinner, Jim?" said Della.

sub_questions.explanation: Jim asked Della if she had cut off her hair. Della replied that she had cut it off and sold it. Then she asked him if he didn't like her just as well, anyhow. She also emphatically said that she was herself without her hair. Being shocked, Jim asked her if she (D) said that her hair was gone. Della replied that he didn't have to look for it and asked him if they would eat dinner.

questions.uddipok:
Read the passage and then write the antonym or synonym of the words as directed below. Make your own sentences with the new words.
Books are the unique medium through which we contact mighty minds of ages. Books tell us about their feelings what they said and what they did. Books are one of the greatest friends to us. They introduce us with the best humanity. They are reliable records of the history. A book is a valuable living voice. We can know about the thoughts and rituals of pastmen through books. We should read good books and avoid worthless ones. A good book is a friend of loneliness and a nurse in ailment. We can find real happiness by reading good books.

(a) unique (antonym); (b) mighty (antonym); (c) humanity (synonym); (d) reliable (antonym); (e) valuable (antonym); (f) ritual (synonym); (g) worthless (synonym); (h) loneliness (synonym); (i) ailment (synonym); (j) happiness (antonym).

sub_questions.explanation:
(a) Unique (antonym) – common.
(b) Mighty (antonym) – weak.
(c) Humanity (synonym) – mankind.
(d) Reliable (antonym) – unreliable.
(e) Valuable (antonym) – worthless
(f) Ritual (synonym) – custom.
(g) Worthless (synonym) – useless.
(h) Loneliness (synonym) – solitude.
(i) Ailment (synonym) – illness.
(j) Happiness (antonym) – misery.

questions.uddipok:
Suppose, you are a staff reporter of a national daily. You are asked by the authority to write a report on the
devastating consequences of drug addiction in the context of Bangladesh.

sub_questions.explanation:
Devastating consequences of drug addiction


Mizanur Rahman, Uttara, Dhaka, 10 January : The number of drug addicts in Bangladesh is increasing day by day. Most of them are unemployed and frustrated youths, coming of noble families. They have become a great headache to their parents. It is reported that a number of youths belonging to the respectable families have already gone astray owing to the fatal trap of drugs. They do not feel hesitant to commit any crime like robbery, snatching, kidnapping, killing just to collect money to buy harmful drugs. Taking harmful drugs, they cause great harm to their bodies. They create disturbance not only in their own family but also  in society. Social stability is hampered by them. As they lose morality, they do not feel bad to tease girls or women and eve to rape them.


According to the dependable sources, most of the cities and towns of Bangladesh have become the crime zone. Specially the slum areas are the sanctuary of the drug businessmen and the addicted. Consequently people cannot sleep opening their windows. Passers-by don’t feel secured at night. Because the addicts disturb them and snatch their belongings.



Government should take necessary measures to stop drug trafficking and help the addicted youths to come back to normal life.

The Celebration of Pahela Boishakh
Pahela Boishakh is the first day of Bangla year. In fact, it is the day of welcoming the Bangla New Year. It is part and parcel of Bengali culture and tradition (ঐতিহ্য). So, the day is observed with traditional festivity (উল্লাস) across the country. People in villages celebrate this day as per their agelong customs. Special meals are arranged at home and Boishakhi Melas are held in different places. It is a day of great pleasure to the village people and children. City dwellers (নগরবাসী) also celebrate this day with delight. Girls and women put on yellow saris and boys put on pajamapanjabi. Some people eat watered-rice with onion, green chilli and hilsha fish. Shopkeepers in both towns and villages open new accounts books (হালখাতা) and offer sweets to their customers and this is the most impressive part of the celebration. Different cultural organizations offer different programmes. The celebration of Pahela Boishakh bears a great importance for us. It is passed by holding and enjoying festive programmes and functions. People living in Dhaka attend the Gano Sangeeter Ashor at Ramna Batamul in the morning. We reap great benefits from this kind of festival. It makes us stick to our traditional native culture. At the same time, it strengthens national unity making us forget the differences of religion, colour, race, etc. On this day, we get inspired to forget all the sorrows and failures (ব্যর্থতা) of the past year and to start a new life. with new vigour (বলিষ্ঠতা) and inspiration.

questions.uddipok:
Recently the female leadership of Bangladesh has been praised superbly in an international conference in India.
Now, write a short composition on “ Students and Social Service ” using 200-250 words.

sub_questions.explanation:
We, the students of Bangladesh, are the future of our country. As youth, we have energy and passion that can be used to improve society. Though our main duty is to study hard, we also have a responsibility to help others in need.
There are many problems in our communities that we can try to solve through social work. Many people in villages and slums are uneducated. During holidays, we students can go to these areas to teach basic reading and writing. We can start makeshift schools under trees to educate both children and adults. Knowledge is power, and education can uplift their lives.
Poverty is also widespread across Bangladesh. We can encourage self-sufficiency by teaching vocational skills like sewing, farming, and small business management. We can work with microfinance organizations to help villagers take small loans to start their own enterprises. Financial independence can alleviate their hardship.
Health awareness is lacking, especially among the poor. We can educate people about cleanliness, nutrition, vaccinations, and preventive care. Girls can be especially effective in teaching women about maternal health, childcare and women’s rights. We can also run free health camps for checkups and medicine distribution.
Some regions face problems like water scarcity. We can mobilize resources to build wells and set up water filters to provide clean drinking water. We can teach sustainable practices like rainwater harvesting that people can implement themselves. Ensuring water access can greatly improve quality of life.
When floods, cyclones and other disasters hit Bangladesh, students can jump into action as volunteers. We can collect food, clothes and medicine to distribute to affected families. We can also directly participate in response efforts by helping evacuate people, setting up shelters, and providing emergency medical aid.
As youth, we represent progress, compassion and social justice. Every small effort we make improves our communities. The young generation has energy and inspiration that is vital for national development. Through continued education and service, we can create solutions and uplift our nation. We, the students of today, will lead Bangladesh towards prosperity tomorrow.
